title: Kenya: BAT Backs Flat Rate Tax on Tobacco
text:
Kenya: Al Shabaab Impersonators Hack the Star Website By Martin Mwita 
Tobacco manufacture British American Tobacco wants the the Excise Duty Bill 2015 retained as originally proposed by Treasury. 
According to the company, new proposals by Parliament will make tax computation difficult, less transparent and will end up reducing revenues for the Treasury. 
The Excise Duty Bill 2015 had proposed that cigarettes containing tobacco or tobacco substitutes be charged a flat duty of Sh2,500 per 1,000 sticks. 
Parliament has recommended that plain cigarettes or cigarettes with an ex-factory selling price of up to Sh2,750 per 1,000 be taxed Sh900. 
Cigarettes in soft-cap packaging with a selling price of between Sh2,751 and Sh3, 750 per 1000 will be taxed Sh1,200. 
Soft cup cigarettes with ex-factory selling price of Sh3,751 to Sh4, 750 per 1,000 be taxed Sh1,800. 
Hinge lid cigarettes or cigarettes with ex-factory selling price of more than Sh4,750 per 1,000 will attract a tax of Sh2,800. 
"We support a single specific excise system for Kenya. We think it is easy to administer and we think it is internationally recognised and the way forward for cigarettes taxation here (Kenya). Regulation is reality and we don't fight regulations but we support balanced regulation," said Keith Gretton, BAT Kenya managing director. 
He was speaking in Nairobi yesterday during the opening of the company's new Sh152 million cut rag tobacco store, by industrialization cabinet secretary Aden Mohamed. 
Mohamed said the government does not target to cripple any manufacture, but is keen to ensure a conducive business environment. Kenya
